title-group.article-title: Protective role of methanol extracts of two lichens on oxidative and genotoxic damage caused by AFB1 in human lymphocytes in vitro

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Biology Teacher Training, Ataturk University, Erzurum, Turkey
2Department of Biology, Ataturk University, Erzurum, Turkey
3Department of Biology, Fatih University, Istanbul, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Lokman Alpsoy, Department of Biology, Fatih University, Istanbul 34500, Turkey. Email: lalpsoy@fatih.edu.tr

abstract.p: In this study, the antigenotoxic and antioxidant effects of Umbilicaria vellea (UME) and Xantho somloensis (XME) extracts were determined using sister chromatid exchange (SCE), micronuclei (MN) assays, and superoxide dismutase (SOD) and glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activities and malondialdehyde (MDA) levels against the effects of aflatoxin B1 (AFB1)-induced oxidative stress and genotoxicity in human lymphocytes in vitro. The results showed that the frequencies of SCE, MN, and MDA level decreased, but the activities of SOD and GPx increased when 5 μg/mL and 10 μg/mL doses of UME and XME were added to AFB1-treated cultures. Also the present results indicate that strong antioxidative and the antigenotoxicity mechanisms of UME and XME are associated with its antioxidant nature.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lichens are symbiotic organisms composed of fungi and algae (Nash, 1996). Species of lichens are distributed in most of the environmental habitats of the world. Lichens have been used extensively in traditional medicine in the world to treat a variety of disorders such as fever, epilepsy, tuberculosis, gout, external wounds, jaundice, and so on. Chemical studies on the secondary metabolites present in lichens have led to the isolation of many new substances, which by today number over 800 (Huneck, 1991; Muller, 2001). These compounds, which comprise aliphatic, cycloaliphatic, aromatic, and terpenic compounds, are unique with respect to those of higher plants and show interesting biological and pharmacological activities (Huneck, 1991; Muller, 2001). Secondary metabolites isolated from lichens have been reported to show a wide variety of biological activities, including antibiotic, antimicrobacterial, antiviral, anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antipyretic, antiproliferative, antioxidant, plant growth inhibitory, and antitumor and cytotoxic effects (Huneck, 1999).

Recently, different extracts of lichens have demonstrated antimutagenic and antigenotoxic activities in mammalian and bacterial cell systems (Geyikoglu et al., 2007; Russo et al., 2002b; Russo et al., 2008; Turkez et al., 2010; Zeytinoglu et al., 2008). Zeytinoglu et al. (2008) showed that the extract of Cetrari aculeata has a significant antigenotoxic activity in bacterial systems, but not in mammalian cells, and cytotoxic activity in some mammalian cancer. In additional, Turkez et al. (2010) found that methanol, acetone, and n-hexane extracts obtained from Pseudovernia furfuracea have antigenotoxic effect and antioxidant capacity in human lymphocytes in vitro. In these studies, the antimutagenic effects of the lichen extracts have been linked with the antioxidant activity of lichens (Geyikoglu et al., 2007; Russo et al., 2002a, 2008; Turkez et al., 2010; Zeytinoglu et al., 2008).

Xanthoparmelia genus produces at least 92 secondary metabolites with a diverse chemical structure (phenolic compound such as depsides, depsidones, antraquinones and monocyclic compounds, as well as aliphatic acids; Hale, 1990; Lumbsch, 2002). Some of these compounds have been studied from a pharmacological point of view as antioxidants, antibiotics, anticancer and anti-HIV agents (Amo de Paz et al., 2010; Bézivin et al., 2003; Lauterwein et al., 1995; Lohézic-Le Devehat et al., 2007).

In another study, Czeczuga and Alstrup (1987) reported that in the three representatives of the Umbilicariaceae, seven carotenoids were identified. β-Cryptoxanthin, lutein, lutein epoxide, and zeaxanthin were present in all species, but the finding of lycophyll in Umbilicaria vellea thalli was worthy of note.

Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) is the most potent carcinogen ever tested and is known to cause hepatotoxicity, teratogenicity, immunotoxicity, and even death in animals and humans (Guindon et al., 2007; Umarani et al., 2008). AFB1 causes micronucleus (MN), sister chromatid exchanges (SCEs), unscheduled DNA synthesis, and chromosomal strand breaks as well as forms adducts in rodent and human cells (Groopman and Kensler, 1998). Mutations play an important role in various diseases including cancer. Oxidative damage and lipid peroxidation (LPO) have been considered to be the main mechanisms of AFB1toxicity, although the mechanism of cellular damage caused by AFB1 has not been fully elucidated (Rastogi et al., 2001; Sohn et al., 2003).

U. vellea and Xantho somloensis have many antioxidative compounds; therefore, in this study, we investigated the antigenotoxic and antioxidative effects of U. vellea (UME) and X. somloensis (XME) extracts against AFB1 in the human blood culture using SCE, MN tests, and biochemical analysis including superoxide dismutase (SOD) and glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activities, and malondialdehyde (MDA) level.

sec.title: Plant material
sec.p: Lichen samples (U. vellea and X. somloensis) were collected from one station in July 2009 in Giresun province, Turkey. This species was collected on soil. It was identified in the laboratory of lichenology at the Department of Biology by Dr Aslan using various flora books and different papers (Aslan, 2000, 2002). The lichen herbarium sample is stored in the herbarium of Kazım Karabekir Education Faculty, Ataturk University, Erzurum.

sec.title: Preparation of methanol extracts
sec.p: Air-dried and powdered lichens (10 g) were extracted with 250 mL of methanol using the Soxhlet extractor (Isopad, Heidelberg, Germany) for 72 h at a temperature not exceeding the boiling point of the solvent (Lin et al., 1999). The extract was filtered using Whatman filter paper (no. 1) and then concentrated in vacuum at 40°C using a rotary evaporator (Buchi Labortechnic AG, Flawil, Switzerland), yielding a waxy material. The extract was then lyophilized and kept in the dark at 4°C until tested.

sec.title: Cytogenetic analysis
sec.p:
Peripheral blood lymphocytes were taken from four nonsmoking healthy donors between the age of 26 and 28. Lymphocyte cultures were set up by adding 0.5 mL of heparinized whole blood to RPMI-1640 chromosome medium supplemented with 15% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum, 100 IU/mL streptomycin, 100 IU/mL penicillin, and 1% l-glutamine. Lymphocytes were stimulated to divide by 1% phytohemagglutinin (PHA). AFB1 (in concentration of 5 and 10 μM), UME, and XME (in concentrations of 5 and 10 μg/mL) were added to the cultures just before incubation. The experiments were performed on 11 groups as follows:
Group 1: Control
Group 2: 5 μM AFB1
Group 3: 10 μM AFB1
Group 4: 5 μM AFB1 + UME (5 μg/mL)
Group 5: 5 μM AFB1 + UME (10 μg/mL)
Group 6: 10 μM AFB1 + UME (5 μg/mL)
Group 7: 10 μM AFB1 + UME (10 μg/mL)
Group 8: 5 μM AFB1 + XME (5 μg/mL)
Group 9: 5 μM AFB1 + XME (10 μg/mL)
Group 10: 10 μM AFB1 + XME (5 μg/mL)
Group 11: 10 μM AFB1 + XME (10 µg/mL)
For SCE demonstration, the cultures were incubated at 37°C for 72 h, and 5-bromo 2-deoxyuridine at 8 mg/mL was added at the initiation of cultures. All cultures were maintained in darkness. Next, 0.1 mg/mL of colcemide was added 3 h before harvesting to arrest the cells at metaphase. The cultures were centrifuged at 800g for 10 min. Cells were harvested and treated for 30 min with hypotonic solution (0.075 M potassium chloride [KCl]) and fixed in a 1:3 mixture of acetic acid/methanol (volume/volume [v/v]). Bromodeoxyuridine-incorporated metaphase chromosomes were stained with fluorescence plus Giemsa technique, as described by Perry and Evans (1975). In SCE study, by selecting 30 satisfactory metaphases, the results of SCE were recorded on the evaluation table. For each treatment condition, well-spread second division metaphases containing 42–46 chromosomes in each cell were scored, and the values obtained were calculated as SCEs per cell.

For MN analysis, cytochalasin B was added 44 h after PHA stimulation to a final concentration of 3 g/mL. Twenty-eight hours later (after 72 h of culture), the cells were harvested by centrifugation (900g, 10 min). The supernatant was removed, the cells were mixed thoroughly and 5 mL of cold hypotonic solution (0.05 M KCl) was added. The cells were subsequently incubated at 37°C for 20 min and centrifuged again (900g, 10 min). The pellet was mixed thoroughly and 5 mL fresh fixative (1:3 acetic acid:methanol) was added dropwise. This fixation procedure was repeated three times and the tube was centrifuged again. The cell pellet was then resuspended in 1 mL of fresh fixative, dropped on to a clean microscope slide, incubated at 37°C or at room temperature overnight, and stained with Giemsa dye. Coded slides were scored blind by two independent individuals. Only binucleated cells were scored for MN analysis. For each subject, at least 2000 binucleated cells were analyzed for the presence of MN. For the MN scoring, the micronucleus criteria described by Countryman and Heddle (1976) were used: a diameter less than one third of the main nucleus, non-refractivity, not touching, and with the same color as the main nucleus or lighter.

sec.title: Biochemical analysis
sec.p: The cell homogenates were prepared at a 1:10 (weight:volume [w:v]) dilution in 10 mM potassium phosphate buffer, pH 7.4. Samples were centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 10 min at 4°C, and the supernatants were collected and immediately assayed for enzyme activities. All samples were measured in sixfold.

sec.title: SOD assay
sec.p: Cu, Zn-SOD activity in the cell culture supernatant was detected by the method of (Sun et al., 1988). A 2.45 mL of assay reagent (0.3 mM xanthine, 0.6 mM Na2EDTA, 0.15 mM nitroblue tetrazolium [NBT], 0.4 M sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), and 1 g/L bovine serum albumin) was combined with 100 μL of the sample. Xanthine oxidase (50 μL, 167 U/L) was added to initiate the reaction, and the reduction of NBT by superoxide anion radicals, which are produced by the xanthine–xanthine oxidase system, was determined by measuring the absorbance at 560 nm. Cu, Zn-SOD activity was expressed in units of SOD per mg protein, where 1 U is defined as that amount of enzyme causing half-maximal inhibition of NBT reduction.

GPx assay. GPx activity in the cell culture supernatant was measured by the method of Paglia and Valentine (1967). Briefly, 50 μL of sample was combined with 100 μL of 8 mM nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate reduced (NADPH), 100 μL of 150 mM reduced GSH, 20 μL of glutathione reductase (30 U/mL), 20 μL of 0.12 M sodium azide solution, and 2.65 mL of 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.0, 5 mM EDTA) and the tubes were incubated for 30 min at 37°C. The reaction was initiated with the addition of 100 μL of 2 mM H2O2 solution, mixed rapidly by inversion, and the conversion of NADPH to nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP) was measured spectrophotometrically for 5 min at 340 nm. The enzyme activity was expressed as units per gram of protein using an extinction coefficient for NADPH at 340 nm of 6.22 × 10−6.

MDA assay. MDA levels in the cell culture supernatant were determined spectrophotometrically, according to the method described by Ohkawa et al. (1979). A mixture of 8.1% sodium dodecyl sulphate, 20% acetic acid, and 0.9% thiobarbituric acid was added to 0.2 mL of sample, and distilled water was added to the mixture to bring the total volume up to 4 mL. This mixture was incubated at 95°C for 1 h. After incubation, the tubes were left to cool under cold water and 1 mL distilled water with 5 mL n-butanol/pyridine (15:1, v/v) was added, followed by mixing up. The samples were centrifuged at 4000g for 10 min. The supernatants were removed, and the absorbances were measured with respect to a blank at 532 nm. 1,1,3,3-Tetraethoxypropane was used as the standard. Lipid peroxide levels were expressed as μmol/L MDA. Protein concentrations in the cell culture supernatant were determined by Bradford method (Bradford, 1976). All photometrical measurements were performed with a DU 530 spectrophotometer (Beckman Instruments, Fullerton, CA, USA) in a quartz cuvette.

Statistical analysis. The statistical analysis of MN frequencies was performed using the χ2 test. A p value of ≤0.05 was regarded as statistically significant for all tests used. For statistical analysis of biochemical parameters and analysis of SCE values Mann–Whitney U test was used. Results were expressed as mean ± SD. For these procedures, SPSS 11.5 version for Windows (SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL, USA) was used.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Tables 1 and 2 show the number of SCEs and MN obtained with two concentrations of AFB1 and different concentrations of UME and XME together with AFB1 on lymphocytes, respectively. Two different doses of AFB1 caused significant SCE and MN formations as seen in Tables 1 and 2. However, SCE and MN frequencies decreased significantly after treatment with AFB1 and 5 and 10 μg/mL UME and XME (p < 0.001 and p < 0.05). Besides, the effect of lichen extracts on antioxidant capacity in human blood cells induced by AFB1 was determined by the activities of enzymes SOD, GPx, and MDA.

caption.p: The frequencies of MN and SCEs in blood lymphocytes after exposure to different doses of AFB1 and UME

cFor SCE p < 0.05 compared with AFB1 (5 μM) group.
dFor MN p < 0.001 compared withAFB1 (5 μM) group.
eFor SCE p < 0.05 compared with AFB1 (10 μM) group.
fFor MN p < 0.001 compared with AFB1 (10 μM) group.

caption.p: The frequencies of MN and SCEs in blood lymphocytes after exposure to different doses of AFB1 and XME

fn.p: AFB1: aflatoxin B1, MN: micronuclei, SCE: sister chromatid exchange, XME: Xantho somloensis extract.
aFor SCE p < 0.001 compared with control group.
bFor MN p < 0.001 compared with control group.
cFor SCE p < 0.05 compared with AFB1 (5 μM) group.
dFor SCE p < 0.001 compared with AFB1 (5 μM) group.
eFor SCE p < 0.001 compared with AFB1 (10 μM) group.
fFor MN p < 0.001 compared with AFB1 (10 μM) group.

sec.p: As shown in the results in Tables 3 and 4, significant reduction in the activities of antioxidant enzymes was found in AFB1-treated group (5 and 10 μM) and level of MDA was significantly higher when compared with the control (p < 0.001). However, these effects of AFB1 seen at higher levels decreased after treatment with two lichen extracts at different concentrations. Such an increase was found to be statistically significant (p < 0.001 and p < 0.05).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of the present study showed that AFB1 indicates a significant increase in the ratios of the SCEs and MNs in lymphocytes. Previous studies found that AFB1 is mutagenic in many model systems and produces CA, MN, SCE, unscheduled DNA synthesis, and chromosomal strand breaks as well as forms adducts in rodent and human cells (Alpsoy et al., 2009a,b; Wang and Groopman, 1999). But after the treatment with UME and XME, the ratios of the SCEs and MNs decreased significantly and the values were comparable with that of the AFB1-treated groups. Our present results showed that the extracts of lichens have antimutagenic effects. UME has stronger antimutagenic activity than XME; but there is no significant difference between UME and XME statistically. In previous studies, extracts of some lichens have shown antimutagenic effects with comet assay, terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase dUTP nick end labeling (TUNEL) assay, SCE, and MN in human lymphocytes and Salmonella typhimurium (TA100 and TA98) assay (Geyikoglu and Turkez, 2008; Russo et al., 2002a; Zeytinoglu et al., 2004). In these studies, the antimutagenic effect of the lichen extracts has been linked with lichestrerinic acid, protolichesterinic acid, usnic acid, polysaccharide Ci-3, sphaerophorin, and pannarin isolated from these lichens (Ingolfsdottir et al., 1998; Orange et al., 2001; Russo et al., 2002a; Zeytinoglu et al., 2004).

In additional, in the present study, SOD, GPx activities, and MDA level were measured to determine the antioxidant effect of XME and UME. Our results showed that AFB1 treatment caused a decrease in SOD and GPx activities and an increase in MDA level. As reported in the previous studies, AFB1 caused a decrease in the activities of antioxidant enzymes (SOD and GPx) and an increase in MDA level in animals (Eraslan et al., 2005; Preetha et al., 2006). These effects of AFB1 have been primarily associated with the generation of intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) like superoxide anion (O2 ·−), hydroxyl radical (HO · ), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) during the metabolic processing of AFB1 (Klein et al., 2002; Sharma and Farmer, 2004; Sohn et al., 2003; Towner et al., 2003). But the effects of AFB1 on enzymes decreased after treatment with UME and XME. U. vellea has many different beta-carotene compounds, therefore the antioxidant activities of UME are stronger than XME.

Previous researches have reported the antioxidant capacity of some lichens and the antioxidant effect of the lichen extract have been linked with polyphenolic compounds such as depsides, depsidones, antraquinones, monocyclic compounds, salazinic acid, stictic acid, epigallocatecthin gallate, quercetin, gallic acid, curcumin, eugenol, usnic acid, polysaccharide Ci-3, lichestrerinic acid, protolichesterinic acid, and nonpolyphenolic isolates such as carotenoids, β-cryptoxanthin, lutein, lutein epoxide, zeaxanthin and lycophyll from these lichens (Halici et al., 2005; Odabasoglu et al., 2004; Russo et al., 2002a). Therefore, our study results indicate that the antigenotoxic effect of UME and XME could be related to its antioxidant potential. The fractionation and isolation of the crude extract of lichen samples containing the active components responsible for antigenotoxic and antioxidant activities are being conducted to test this hypothesis.

In conclusion, lichen substances are poorly studied as a new source of active metabolites. Our findings show that the extracts of both the lichens (U. vellea and X. somloensis) including depsides, depsidones, antraquinones, monocyclic compounds, salazinic acid, stictic acid, usnic acid, carotenoids, β-cryptoxanthin, lutein, lutein epoxide, zeaxanthin, and lycophyll protect against oxidative stress. This suggests the possibility that they could be used as antioxidant agents in those neurodegenerative disorders associated with oxidative damage such as Alzheimer’s disease and Parkinson’s disease.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The authors are grateful to the volunteers for the blood samples.

fn.p: The authors are thankful to the Ataturk University and Fatih University, Research Project Foundation (Contract no: P50031005-2) for financial support of this study.
